newsitem.title: UK: Brent up on paper market, physical.
newsitem.headline: Brent up on paper market, physical.

text.p: Brent rose on the paper market on Thursday with firm intermonth spreads and outright levels and the benchmark North Sea crude seemed stronger on the physical side also, traders said.

There was unconfirmed talk of an early June cargo of Brent sold at July Brent -2 cents, eight cents higher than a deal for a June 5-7 loader of the benchmark crude on Wednesday. On the cash market, July Brent was trading 18 cents a barrel higher at $20.31, just three cents off the day's high reached after New York's WTI contract opened higher than expected. A Brent August paper contract traded once at $20.31, compared with $20.11 a similar contract fetched on Wednesday.

In an active physical market in other North Sea grades, Norwegian grades were steady to a shade easier. A June 10-12 cargo of Statfjord was sold at Dated Brent +31 cents, the same level an end May cargo fetched a day earlier.

A trading house was also reported to have bought a June 6 Ekofisk, with talk of the price in the Dated Brent +10/+13 cents region, and there was unconfirmed talk of a June 5 loader sold at about the same level. "It (Ekofisk) is coming off a bit, it is only Brent that is really strong, the rest of the grades are struggling a bit," the seller of the Statfjord said. He said Brent's strength was coming from shipments out of the area.
Brent's gains of some $2.50 a barrel since the start of May have caused refinery runs to worsen.
Traders said on Thursday afternoon that British Petroleum cut refinery runs at its Rotterdam refinery by 40 percent from midnight on Wednesday due to poor margins.

They said BP, which controls 65 percent of 400,000 bpd Rotterdam Nerefco refinery, had cut runs by the equivalent of 10 percent for the month of May, which translated into a 40 percent cut for the balance of May.
Last week, Texaco cut crude runs at the refinery by the equivalent of 20 percent for the second half of May.

But other ARA refiners were holding back from cutting runs on Thursday, traders said. Prompt Brent Contracts for Difference (CFDs) strengthened further with May 27-30 traded once at July Brent flat after earlier trades at a seven cents discount to July Brent.

But next week's CFD eased some seven cents to trade at July Brent -15 in the afternoon while Jun 9-13 was offered two cents weaker at July Brent -12 cents. Brent intermonth spreads rose in late talk with June July talked +7/+10 after trading at +6 cents in the afternoon, just one cent off an earlier trade. Jul/Sep traded four times at +3 cents.

Jul/Aug and A/S eached gained one to two cents in late talk to +1/+3 cents and 0/+2 cents. The single Brent cargo turning wet on Thursday was kept by Suko ahead of the five o'clock deadline, traders said. The cargo is due to load in the June 6-8 period. In the Mediterranean Russian Urals was still pressured, with late May barrels talked in the Dated Brent -$1.45 region and early June barrels some 10 cens firmer.

A cargo of Urals loading May 27-29 changed hands at Dated Brent -$1.42 on Wednesday, four cents adrift from the value achieved for a distressed parcel a day earlier. Traders were seeking information about the fate of a Urals offered on the water at around Dated Brent -$1.40.
"We see potential buyer interest for early June barrels at (Dated Brent) - $1.35 but seller are not there at that price so nothing is happening. It is a quiet day," one trader said.

Traders earlier said they had no word on the status of the loading on May 25 of a one million barrel cargo of Iraqi Kirkuk at Turkey's Ceyhan port. Some traders said they doubted there would be any cancellations of Kirkuk liftings under Baghdad's $2 billion "oil-for-food" deal with the United Nations but said there could be some delays.
"There could be some delay, resulting from administrative reasons but I don't see any big problems, probably no cancellations (of liftings)," a trader said.
A senior U.N. official said on Thursday that a rollover of the oil-for-food plan for Iraq is a "foregone conclusion" presumably at the current $2 billion level.
Yasushi Akashi, undersecretary-general for humanitarian affairs, told reporters that renewal of the plan was virtually assured at current sales levels.

A senior U.N. official told Reuters on Wednesday that U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan was expected to recommend by the end of the month that the deal be renewed in June on the same terms as the present six-month plan. The West African market was quiet, still absorbing Nigeria's Official Selling Price issued late on Tuesday, with traders saying that the higher numbers have disappointed some market players. --Haitham Haddadin, London newsroom +44 171 542 8145
